Mrs. Ra B., 51, and her husband, Mr. Chuy Cheng, 66, who live about 20 kilometres from Phnom Penh, were married in 1981 and have four children, three sons and one daughter. One of their children is married but lives in the family home, while the other three have full time employment.

Mrs. Ra and her husband have been selling fried bananas, a very popular dessert in Cambodia, for two years. They take powder to mix with egg, coconut, and water into which they dip the banana and fry it. Ra is now requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase a motorcycle for her children to drive to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for her children to drive to work.

loans.name: Meas

texts.en:
Mrs. Meas C., 27, is a Cambodian noodle maker, earning approximately $4 per day. Her husband works with her to make the noodles. They sell their noodles to other retailers in her area.

C. is requesting a loan in the amount of $1,000 to purchase a noodle-making machine. She will use the remainder of the loan is to purchase piglets to raise and then sell for profit at local markets. The loan will allow her to increase her noodle production and hopefully expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase a noodle-making machine

loans.name: Pon

texts.en:
Mrs. Pon R. is a stove maker in Tie Prumpie Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. Her husband, Mr. Tin Phan, helps his wife. They have three children, two of whom are working as construction workers while the third is a motorbike-taxi driver who earns only a small income because the price of gasoline has gone up and his old motorbike uses a lot of gasoline at a time.

Thus, Mrs. Pon R. is requesting a loan so she can buy a new motorbike for her son. Mrs. Pon R. obtained a previous loan from AMK to buy clay to make stoves and she has fully repaid this loan. Mrs. Pon R. and her husband are shown in the picture.

loans.use: To buy a new motorbike for her son's business.

loans.name: Teko

texts.fr:
Agée de 40 ans, Madame K. Teko est mariée et mère de trois enfants. Sa famille vit des maigres bénéfices de son activité de préparation et de vente de riz.

Face à l’augmentation des charges du ménage, à la paupérisation continuelle et aux difficiles conditions d’existence de celui ci, Teko décide d’augmenter son pouvoir d’achat en sollicitant un crédit.

Ceci lui permettra de maximiser de bénéfice afin d’améliorer les conditions et niveau de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Teko K. is 40 years old and married with three children. Her family lives on the small profits from her business making and selling rice.

Because of the increase of her household expenses, the continual impoverishment and her difficult living conditions, Teko decided to increase her buying power by requesting a loan.

This will enable her to maximize her profits so that she can improve her family's quality of life.

Translated from French by Alex Jaffe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase rice, dough, oil and fish

loans.name: Rosario Beatriz

texts.es:
La señora Rosario pertenece al Banco Comunal “Las Paykanas”, ubicado en Jr: La Unión Nº 294, distrito de Manantay, departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 31 años de edad, es madre de 3 hijos menores de edad que aún depende de ella, es casada y su esposo trabaja en un taller de mecánica. Con el primer préstamo que recibió de Manuela Ramos de S/.300, decide invertir en la venta de abarrotes. Tiene 3 años participando en Manuela Ramos. 

En la actualidad cuenta con una bodega en casa y también vende comida por las noches. En el negocio de comida se podrá encontrar juanes, salchipapa y otros antojitos.

Con este préstamo de S/.1,200, el cual será cancelado en 4 meses, comprará 1 saco de azúcar, 1 saco de arroz, 1 caja de leche, toallas higiénicas, huevos, papel higiénico, etc., y de esa manera le están dando la oportunidad de ampliar el negocio.  
   
Rosario se siente feliz, porque día a día mejora su negocio, y está muy contenta con todo lo que ha logrado.
texts.en:
La señora Rosario belongs to the community bank "Las Paykanas", located in Jr: La Unión Nº 294, district of Manantay, department of Ucayali. She is 31 years of age, is the mother of three young children that still depend on her, is married, and her husband works in a mechanic's shop. With the first loan she received from Manuela Ramos of S/.300, she decided to invest it in the sale of groceries. She has participated in Manuela Ramos for three years.

Currently, she has a store in her home and also sells food at night. In her food business you can find "juanes" (steam cooked rice dough with or without a filling), salchipapa (dish that contains potato and fried sausage), and other snacks.

With this loan of S/.1,200 ($400), which will be repaid in 4 months, she will buy 1 sack of sugar, 1 sack of rice, 1 box of milk, sanitary pads, eggs, toilet paper, etc., and in this way give her the opportunity to increase her business.

Rosario feels happy because day by day her business improves and she is very content with everything that she has achieved.

Translated from Spanish by Joanna Silverman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: She will buy sugar, rice, milk, eggs, etc.

loans.name: Lay

texts.en:
Mrs. Lay S., 53, and her husband, Mr. Kong Bou, 51, live along National Road Number One about seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1979 and have seven children: six sons and one daughter. Two of their children are married and live outside the family home. Two other children have full time employment. Two sons study in local schools.

Mrs. Lay has been selling fish since 1992. She buys them from a fishing lot a bit far from her home to sell at the Phnom Penh market and in her village market. Her husband is a chef and assists Lay in the fish selling business.

Lay is requesting a loan of $700 to purchase more fish for resale.

loans.use: To purchase fish for resale

loans.name: Komla

texts.fr: Komla H. est un soudeur redoutable depuis 5 ans à Atakpamé, une ville située au centre du Togo. Agé de 45 ans, il est marié et père de 4 enfants. Il souhaite avec ce crédit acheter des outils de travail afin d’offrir un service de qualité à la clientèle et aussi aménager son garage. Ceci lui permettra de gagner plus d’argent pour mieux subvenir aux besoins de sa famille
texts.en:
Komla H. has been a formidable welder for five years in Atakpamé, a city located in the middle of Togo. He is 45 years old, married, and the father of four. He would like to use this loan to buy work tools in order to provide quality service to customers and also to fix up his garage. This will enable him to earn more money to provide for his family better.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy work tools and to fix up his garage

loans.name: Revelyn

texts.en:
Revelyn, married with five children, lives in Barangay Lullutan. She has a community-based variety store which generates an average daily net income of Php150.  Most of her customers are farmers and fishermen, since the major sources of livelihood in this area are farming and fishing.
	
Twice a week, she goes to the town of Ilagan to purchase needed commodities. To cross Lullutan River, she must ride a ferryboat. “Bringing back the purchased items is very risky, costly, and time consuming. That is why I am thinking of going to the market just once a week,” Revelyn added. 

She believes that increasing her products will give her more profit and savings.She will be able to provide what the people in her community need and, therefore, they do not need to go to the town. She will need additional money amounting to Php7,000 to realize her plan.  She is so hopeful that, with the increased income and savings, her family’s life will be a lot better, and it will enable her to send her children to good school.

loans.use: Additional capital

loans.name: Maris

texts.es: Maris tiene 40 años, es viuda y vive con su hijo. Está dedicada a las cabinas de Internet que instaló hace un año con mucho esfuerzo, ya que anteriormente se dedicaba a la venta de chompas que llevaba a las zonas mineras, ya que los mineros las compraban grandes cantidades, gracias a estas ventas pudo ahorrar y así abrir su nuevo negocio en su casa, donde atiende  todo el día, tratando de estar siempre dispuesta a brindar la mejor atención a sus clientes, pero a la vez tiene que tener sumo cuidado por los frecuentes robos que hay en su zona, por ello trata de ser muy selectiva con sus clientes. Maris está en su tercer crédito con MFP, y como una mujer muy responsable siempre pagó puntualmente sus cuotas en las reuniones correspondientes. Con el dinero solicitado adquirirá unas vitrinas para vender algunos dulces que  sus clientes degusten y así tener ingresos adicionales.
texts.en:
Maris is 40 years old. She is a widow and lives with her son. She has an Internet cafe that she installed with a lot of effort a year ago. She used to sell sweaters that she took to the mining areas because the miners would buy them in large quantities. Thanks to these sales, she was able to save and open her new business in her house. She works all day and tries to always be available to offer her customers the best service. At the same time she has to be extremely careful because of the frequent thefts in her area and therefore she tries to be selective concerning her customers. Maris is on her third loan with MFP (Microfinanzas Prisma). She is a very responsible woman and has always made her payments on time at the meetings. With the money she has requested, she would purchase display cabinets to sell some candy for her customers to sample and this way have additional income.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Haynes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase display cabinets to sell candy in her business

loans.name: Rosalie

texts.en:
Rosalie has a dry goods business located in the public market of Tumauini, Isabela.  She sells different kinds of clothing but she also wants to sell other kinds of products to increase her income.  She is asking for a loan of PHP 10,000.00 to realize her plans. At the moment, her focus is on the maintenance and development of her business because it is their source of income.  She believes that hard work, good attitude and wise strategies are some of the keys for her to become successful.

She is already married and they have a three year old daughter named Kyana.  Her husband is a farmer who also assists her in their store when he is not busy in the farm.

loans.use: purchase additional products to sell in her store

loans.name: Clara

texts.es:
Clara  inició el negocio por deseos de superación y de salir adelante con la ayuda de su pareja para poder brindarle mejor atención médica a su hija Blanca Estela que es discapacitada, y así pueda ir mejorando cada día. Comenzó el negocio en Febrero de 2005 ayudándole a una tía y ella le daba una comisión pero luego ella le insistió que ella iniciara un negocio propio para que toda la ganancia fuera para ella, y aunque tardo un poco en animarse, finalmente aceptò, de lo cual no se arrepiento porque realmente le deja muy buena ganancia y con eso puedo ayudar a su pareja con los gastos de la casa.   

Poco a poco va teniendo más clientes que compran su producto lo cual ha hecho que también aumenten sus ganancias.

Ella necesita un prestamo por MXN $10,000 que pagara en 10 catorcenas. 
Con este crédito va a comprar más productos para vender en este día de San Valentín que se acerca y en el cual la gente aprovecha para regalar.
texts.en:
Clara began her business because she and her husband want to get ahead. Her daughter Blanca Estela is disabled, and Clara is working to provide better medical care so that her condition will improve.

She began her business in February 2005 by helping her aunt, who provided a commission. Later, her aunt encouraged her to start her own business so that all of her earnings would be hers. It took a while for Clara to warm to the idea, but she finally did, and she has never regretted the decision, since she now has a good income and is able to help her husband with the household expenses. She has been able to slowly but surely build her customer base, which has increased her earnings.

Clara is requesting a loan for 10,000 Mexican pesos (US $700), to be repaid in ten installments. With the money, she will buy merchandise for her customers to give as Valentine's Day gifts.

Translated from Spanish by Kris Vickery, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase merchandise

loans.name: Eng

texts.en:
Mr. Eng K., 61, is a widower with seven children: two sons and five daughters. The family lives in a small village along National Road Number Five, about 17 km from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. Two of his daughters are garment factory workers, one son is a motor sale commissioner, two children attend school, and the other two are married and live outside the family home.

Eng has been selling porridge for over six years. He buys ingredients from Prek Phnao market to cook and sell in his village. Eng is in the process of building new house, but he doesn’t have enough money to pay the building fee. He is requesting a loan of $1000 to use for this purpose.

loans.use: To add to his own money to finish building his house.

loans.name: Néné Galle

texts.fr: Madame Néné Galle D. dit Ousmany est une commerçante restauratrice à la gare routière de Thiès, Sénégal depuis 7 ans.  Elle habite au quartier Mbour 1 de Thiès, et elle est mariée.  Pour diversifier ses sources de revenus, elle veut se lancer dans le commerce des basins et d’Indigo.  Ainsi elle sollicite ce prêt pour financer ces activités.  Elle maitrise le domaine et veut développer son commerce.
texts.en:
Ms. Néné Galle D., also called Ousmany, has been a restauranteur-merchant at the bus station of Thiès, Sénégal, for seven years. She lives in the Mbour 1 district of Thiès, and she is married. To diversify her sources of revenues, she wants to start doing commerce in tubs, basins, and indigo. She’s therefore requesting this loan to finance her activities. She’s a master in her domain and wants to develop her commerce.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy basins and indigo

loans.name: Ni Komang Maria Coa

texts.en:
Maria Coa (DNR.M-0637) is a 45-year-old female living in the town of Dsn. Pangkung Liplip, Ds. Kaliakah.  She is married and has two school-aged children. To making a living, Maria Coa owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food & daily use products in the local community.  Maria Coa has been engaged in this business for over three years and earns approximately 1,000,000 IDR a month from these activities.

In 2008, Maria Coa joined DINARI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Maria Coa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000,000 IDR from DINARI.  This previous loan was used to purchase new items to expand her product offerings.  Maria Coa is now requesting a new loan of 5,000,000 IDR, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. The loan will be the second loan taken out by the borrower from DINARI.  Maria Coa plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children's tuition fees.

About DINARI:

The mission of DINARI is to strive for the preservation of the environment, to empower the poor, and to provide socio-economic development opportunities to small business owners.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Bahasa while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

Maria Coa - (DNR.M-0637) merupakan 45 tahun wanita.  Dia (perempuan) tinggal di kota Dsn. Pangkung Liplip, Ds. Kaliakah.  Dia (perempuan) menikah dan memiliki 2 anak usia sekolah.  Untuk membiayai hidup, Maria Coa memiliki & menjalankan usaha.  Bisnis beroperasi di sektor ritel.  Tujuan utama bisnis tersebut adalah membuka toko umum.  Meskipun bukan satu-satunya sarana untuk menghasilkan pendapatan, sumber utama penghasilan bisnis tersebut terutama berasal dari menjual produk makanan & barang kebutuhan sehari-hari di tengah masyarakat setempat.  Maria Coa sudah menjalankan bisnis ini selama lebih dari 3 tahun.  Dari kegiatan-kegiatan ini, Maria Coa menghasilkan sekitar 1,000,000 IDR sebulan.


Dalam 2008, Maria Coa bergabung DINARI untuk mendapatkan akses ke layanan keuangan untuk membantu meningkatkan  -nya kondisi kehidupan dan kemampuan untuk menjalankan kegiatan bisnis.  Maria Coa meminta pinjaman untuk pertama kalinya dari DINARI.  Pinjaman sebelumnya ini digunakan untuk membeli artikel-artikel baru untuk memperluas penawaran produk.  Dia (perempuan) sekarang meminta pinjaman baru sebesar 5,000,000 IDR.  Pinjaman saat ini akan digunakan untuk untuk membeli produk tambahan untuk dijual.  Pinjaman ini akan menjadi 2nd pinjaman yang diambil oleh peminjam dari DINARI.  Maria Coa berencana untuk menggunakan pendapatan tambahan yang dihasilkan dari bisnis  untuk membayar biaya sekolah anak-anak peminjam.


Tentang DINARI:

Misi DINARI adalah memperjuangkan kelestarian lingkungan, memberdayakan kaum miskin, dan menyediakan kesempatan pembangunan sosial ekonomi bagi pemilik usaha kecil.

*Catatan: Untuk memaksimalkan efisiensi & menurunkan biaya, pinjaman ini ditempelkan menggunakan templat sehingga dapat diterjemahkan otomatis oleh Kiva. .  Mengingat bahwa terjemahan manual atas profil memakan biaya besar, Kiva menciptakan templat ini untuk Mitra Lapangan untuk memungkinkan mereka terus menempelkan pinjaman dalam  Bahasa sambil memberikan informasi yang bermutu & akurat kepada para pemberi pinjaman Kiva.  ."

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Afiwa

texts.fr: Cette dame a abandonné les études au lycée, ayant quelques notions de gestion, elle s’est lancée dans la vente de produits d’alimentation générale et de produits cosmétiques, elle a ouvert une boutique qu’elle a appelé « ETS GRACELIA », elle s’approvisionne au grand marché de lomé, elle exerce son commerce non loin d’avédji et est très connu dans son quartier. Une partie de son stock est épuisée, elle voudrait se réapprovisionner et sollicite de WAGES son premier crédit pour renouveller son stock. Elle est mariée et a 03 enfants.
texts.en:
This lady left off her studies at the high school level. Having some notion of managing a business, she began selling groceries and cosmetics. She opened a little shop she calls « ETS GRACELIA ». She buys her supplies in the big open-air market of Lomé. Her sales point is not far from Avédji and is well-known in her neighborhood. Part of her inventory is sold out, and she would like to replenish it. She is requesting her first loan from WAGES to replenish her stock. She is married and the mother of 3 children.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of groceries and cosmetics for re-sale

loans.name: Joy Ann

texts.en:
Joy Ann P. is from the village of Balide, Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 29 years old. Joy Ann is married and has one young child. To make a living, Joy Ann owns and operates a "sari-sari" or general retail store. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling daily-use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste, etc., in the local community. Joy Ann has been engaged in her business for more than three years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Joy Ann joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Joy Ann has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell in her "sari-sari" store. Joy Ann is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will also be used to purchase new items to sell. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Joy Ann from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business and for her family's basic needs.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Carmen

texts.es: Carmen, a sus 31 años tiene que asumir su rol de madre y de padre para su hijo quien es la razón de ser en su vida, y con el apoyo de su sobrino quien vive en su casa puede estar pendiente de su hijo. Desde que se separó de su pareja tuvo que buscar la forma de ganarse la vida sola y encontró en la venta de prendas íntimas una forma  de salir adelante. Estas prendas las compra en el mercado central de la ciudad o en las fábricas, pues los precios son muy cómodos y le permiten tener ganancias considerables. A pesar de ser muy cansada su labor no deja de salir todos los días por las mañanas a la puerta del mercado donde tiene alquilado un espacio y donde muy alegremente oferta su mercadería hasta el medio día. Adicionalmente, vende pescado los fines de semana en el mercado mayorista de su distrito. Carmen espera que los ahorros que ha ido acumulando le permitan pronto conseguir un puesto estable en el mercado para dejar de exponerse al peligro debido a la delincuencia que hay en la zona. Este es su cuarto crédito con Microfinanzas PRISMA, junto a sus compañeras de banco comunal trabajar arduamente para incrementar sus ganancias y hasta la fecha el equipo de trabajo que conformaron viene funcionando responsablemente. Con los 1200 soles que solicita comprará prendas para la temporada de invierno y así aumentar sus ventas.
texts.en:
At 31 years of age, Carmen has to assume the role of mother and father for her son, who is her reason for living. With the help of her nephew, who lives in her house, she can be devoted to her son. After separating from her husband, she had to look for a way to earn a living by herself. She found that selling intimate garments was a way to get ahead. She buys the garments in the central market of the city or in the factories. The prices are very good and they allow her to have considerable earnings. In spite of being very tired from her work, every morning she goes to the entry of the market. She has a rented space there where she happily offers her merchandise until midday. Also, on the weekends she sells fish in the wholesale market in her district . Carmen hopes that the savings she has been accumulating will allow her to get a stable place in the market so that she will no longer be exposed to the danger of the delinquency that exists in her zone. This is her fourth loan with Microfinanzas Prisma. Together with her colleagues from the community bank, she works arduously to increase her earnings. The work team they comprise is functioning very responsibly. The 1,200 PEN will be used to buy garments for the winter. This way she will increase her sales.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase merchandise

loans.name: Voita

texts.en: Voita T., 36, is married and has four children. She has two years of experience in the taro plantation and vegetable business. She sells to the village people and to the public three days a week. She has no previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 200 Tala (~$120 USD).  SPBD loans are Voita’s only access to capital because is not able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase weed killing spray, chemicals, spades, wires, and taro roots

loans.name: Jenny De Los Ángeles

texts.es:
La joven Jenny de los Ángeles G. se dedica arduamente a su actividad de venta de bananos en el mercado Mayoreo en la ciudad de Managua, vendiéndolos a diario desde muy tempranas horas de la mañana hasta el atardecer atendiendo a todos sus clientes en la venta de estas frutas.

Debido a que es una madre responsable y con un pequeño hijo, ella se esfuerza para mantenerlo y lograr sacarlo adelante. Es por ello que ha acudido a Ceprodel para solicitar un crédito para  la compra de los bananos y de esta manera ofertarlos en su localidad en el mercado.
texts.en:
Jenny de los Ángeles G. works arduously selling bananas in the Mayoreo market in the city of Managua. She sells them every day from very early in the morning until dusk. She waits on all of her customers as she sells this fruit. Because she is a responsible mother with a small son, she works hard to support him and give him a good future. That is why is she has come to Ceprodel to ask for a loan to buy bananas. She will sell them from her location in the market.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy bananas

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase stocks of charcoal.

loans.name: Miguelina

texts.es: La señora Miguelina, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Virgen de Guadalupe II”, Distrito de Bagua Grande, Provincia Utcubamba, Departamento de Amazonas. Es conviviente, tiene 39 años tiene 3 hijos, 02 varones y 01 mujer,  todos aun en etapa escolar.  Miguelina, es una mujer muy jovial, alegre y optimista que se inicio vendiendo para otra persona hasta conseguir clientes y animarse a vender para ella, viendo que si le hacían los pedidos y fue cunado una amiga le animó a hacerlo, tal es así que ahora ella vende para ella y aprovecha las ofertas para hacerse de sus productos y venderlos  precio de catálogo y poder ganar mas.En la actualidad tiene una clientela ya fidelizada, ella vende al contado y al crédito con pagos de manera diaria, semanal quincenal o mensual.Con este préstamo de S/ 1,000.00, comprará productos de belleza como colonias, esmaltes, bijuoteria  como aretes, collares y anillos, así como perfumes para varón que salen en ofertas y un exhibidor para poder dar a conocer y cuidar sus productos, quiere tener surtido su negocio y dar una buena  atención a sus clientes y encuentren lo que necesiten. Miguelina, sueña con crecer en este negocio y llegar a ser una vendedora estrella para ganar buenos premios. Agradece a Manuela Ramos por ayudarla a implementar su negocio y también a muchas mujeres que  quieren desarrollarse en lo personal y en el negocio.
texts.en:
Mrs. Miguelina belongs to the community bank Virgin of Guadalupe II in the District of Bagua Grande, Province of Utcubamba, Department of Amazonas. She lives with her partner, is 39 years old, and has three children - two sons and one daughter, all still school age. Miguelina is a very jovial woman, happy and optimistic, who began selling for another person until she got clients and decided to sell for herself. She saw that people were placing orders with her and the brother in law of a friend encouraged her to take the step. That is how she is now in business for herself and takes advantage of the offers to get the products and sell them at catalog prices, earning more. Now she has a very faithful clientele. She sells for cash and on credit, with payments daily, weekly, bi-monthly, or monthly. With this loan of 1000 Soles she will buy beauty products like colognes, nail polish, costume jewelry like earrings, necklaces,and rings. She will also buy cologne for men on special offer, and a display case to be able to show and care for her products. She wants to supply her business and provide good service to her clients so they can find what they need. Miguelina dreams of expanding this business and getting to be a star seller in order to earn good prizes. She thanks Manuela Ramos for helping her to set up her business and also for helping the many women who want to advance themselves personally and in business.

Translated from Spanish by Daniel Burke, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: She will buy catalog products to increase her inventory

loans.name: Poni

texts.en:
Poni C. is currently in the business of selling paste, tomatoes, okra, etc., and is requesting a loan to improve on the stock.  Poni is 32 years old and is married with a husband who is a peasant. She has five children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a hotel and lodge. 

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Improve the stock of items she sells

loans.name: Latré

texts.fr: Cette femme est spécialisée dans la vente de bijoux de qualité au marché de Hédzranawoé à Lomé ; elle a débuté ce commerce en 2003 et elle maîtrise parfaitement son marché. Cette activité lui permet entre autres de subvenir à ses besoins. Elle se rend le plus souvent au Bénin pour acheter des bijoux de qualité, mais aussi au Ghana ; ensuite elle revend ses achats un peu plus chère, ce qui fait qu’elle réalise d’importants bénéfices. Elle vend des colliers, des bagues, des montres-bracelets en or pour dames. Elle est très connue des femmes bureaucrates. Elle prévoit dans l’avenir ouvrir un nouveau point de vente dans le marché de Nukafu, toujours à Lomé. Pour disposer d’un nouveau stock, elle sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour effectuer un tel achat. Elle n’est pas mariée et n’a aucun enfant à sa charge.
texts.en:
This woman specializes in selling high-quality jewelry in the market of Hédzranawoé in Lomé. She started her business in 2003 and has perfectly mastered her business. Amongst other things, this business enables her to This business enables her to pay for her needs. She supplies herself with high-quality jewelry from Benin, but also from Ghana; she re-sells this jewelry at a slightly higher price, which enables her to earn strong profits. She sells necklaces, rings and wrist-watches for women. She is very well-known by female bureaucrats. For the future, she foresees opening a new store in the market of Nukafu, also in Lomé. In order to obtain new stock, she is requesting a loan from the micro-finance institution group WAGES. She is not married and has not children in her care.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase jewelry and necklaces

loans.name: Santa Librada Group

texts.en:
The Committee Santa Librada was formed on February 18th, 2009, in the Neighbhorhood Santa Librada in Yaguarón City. This commitee was started by Rosa S.. Rosa attended a Training Program for Women Entrepreneurs and was very impressed with the idea of a Committee. She got 16 women together who were comfortable with Fundacion Paraguay and with Kiva. 

The group is already in their 3rd cycle of the program and the credit they took was 650,000 PYG. The credit is intended for different activities such as grocery items (rice, sugar, baked goods, milk, etc.), selling clothes, lingerie, ice cream, beverages, and others. All committee members attend weekly meetings and work together to achieve their objectives. They are a very active and supportive group who perform well and demonstrate excellent partnership. Moreover, they have formed friendships in between, and their group promotes accountability and camaraderie within the committee. 
Ingrid T. wants to use her loan to sell used clothes. 
Rosa S. wants to use her loan to sell food. 
María G. wants to use her loan for a grocery store. 
Verónica R. D. wants to use her loan for her sewing business. 
María S. wants to use her loan for tailoring. 
Martina C. wants to use her loan to sell food. 
Idalina R. D. wants to use her loan for groceries. 
Aurora R. D. wants to use her loan for a grocery store. 
Dominga V. wants to use her loan to sell clothes. 
Adelia P. wants to use her loan for a grocery store. 
Evelín R. wants to use her loan to sell clothes. 
Elena Y. wants to use her loan to sell food. 
Rosa

loans.use: To purchase supplies such as clothes, food, beverages.

loans.name: Makhsuda

texts.en:
A. Makhsuda is 45 years old. She is divorced and the mother of 3 children. For 20 years now, Makhsuda has been selling clothing. She sells socks for men and children in the central local market. Makhsuda spends the income from her business for educating of her children as she is dreaming that her children will have a higher education.

Makhsuda has been provided with the loans by IMON for 4 years already . For the entire period of time she has shown herself to be an accurate client. Today she is requesting 5000 Somoni ($1150 USD) to purchase new goods for resale. Makhsuda promises to pay the loan back on time and thanks all supporting her.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing new goods to sell

loans.name: Valentina

texts.en:
Valentina is married and lives in Znamenka village. She owns a small store in a neighboring village where she sells seeds, fertilizers, etc.

Valentina has been in this business for ten years. She moved from a larger town to the village and needed a job. Having an entrepreneurial mind, she decided to start her own business. There was a large agricultural production in a neighboring village, so she decided to sell what was in high demand.

Valentina is a very open person; she is willing to give advice about raising crops to anybody who comes to her store. Her business goal is to start a similar store in her own village.

Valentina would like to borrow 9,128 UAH to increase her assortment. At this time of year, farmers buy seeds and Valentina wants to offer them exactly what they need.

loans.use: To increase her assortment

loans.name: Tem

texts.en: Tem K., 30, is married with two school-aged children. She resides in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia with her husband (pictured) and children. To make a living, she runs a hair dressing shop in her village, earning about US $2.50 per day. Her husband helps her with her business.  He also produces palm sugar, earning approximately US $8 per day. K. and her husband are seeking to improve their standard of living and generate a better income. K. is asking for a loan of US $1000 to purchase a motorbike to transport palm trees and other materials to produce traditional handcrafts as souvenirs for tourists.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike

loans.name: Reina De La Paz Group

texts.es: El banco comunal “Reina de La Paz” esta representado por la señora Sintia y conformado por 14 miembros que ya van cursando su segundo ciclo demostrando responsabilidad y ganas de salir adelante con esfuerzo y dedicación a su trabajo, cada una cuenta con actividades económicas como la venta de pan, empanadas, ropas en el mercado, cosméticos y productos por catalogo que  generalmente realizan su trabajo de forma ambulante, otros se dedican a la venta de gas y a diferentes servicios como el transporte publico de pasajeros, confección de prendas de vestir y al trabajo en diferentes oficinas bajo el cargo de secretaria. La competencia entre ellas depende mucho del tipo de producto que ofrecen por ejemplo aquellas que se dedican a la venta de pan tienen mayor demanda que las que se dedican a la venta de ropa, pero como es grupo unido entre todas se apoyan. El crédito esta destinado a la compra mercadería nueva, insumos, herramientas y repuestos y para algunas para la refacción y mejoramiento de sus viviendas que ayudara a mejorar la calidad de vida de sus familias.
texts.en:
The communal bank "Reina de la Paz" is represented by Sintia and is made up of 14 members. In their second term, they are already showing responsibility and eagerness to get ahead with effort and dedication to their work. Each has economic activities such as selling bread, empanadas, clothes in the market, cosmetics and catalog products. Generally, they carry out their work as street vendors. Others make their living selling gas and with different services such as public passenger transportation, making clothing, and working in different offices in the role of secretary. Their competence depends a lot on the type of product they offer. For example, those that sell bread have a higher demand than those that sell clothes, but since it's a close group they all support each other. The loan is destined for the purchase of new merchandise, ingredients, tools, and replacement parts. For some it's for the repair and improvement of their homes which will help to better their families' quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Ellen Donohue, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating Capital

loans.name: Rosa

texts.en:
Rosa is a client of Asociación Arariwa. She is member of a communal bank consisting of nineteen members in Cusco. The group is called Killa (“moon” in Quechua). Rosa lives with her partner and daughter in Cusco. Her partner works as a tour guide in and around Cusco and he sometimes helps Rosa with her business when he has time. Rosa’s daughter is studying medicine.

Rosa is about to launch a new restaurant in Cusco. She previously ran a snack stand catering mostly to university students, but was motivated by her desire to own and run her own restaurant. The area around the restaurant, on the Plaza Tupac Amaru, has several office buildings, a large police station and municipal buildings, so Rosa expects to have many potential customers.

Rosa used her savings to fully equip the restaurant and now needs a loan to buy food and to pay the four employees she will hire.  Rosa plans to launch her restaurant before the New Year. After receiving the loan proceeds, all that will be left will be for her to decide on a name.

Rosa appreciates and thanks you for the loan and promises to pay the monthly repayments on time.

loans.use: To use as start-up money to run new restaurant

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional stock of soft drinks in bulk.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: purchase of traditional articles, wholesale

loans.name: Florentina

texts.es:
Florentina (56) es una mujer con mucha experiencia en su trabajo. Vive con Félix, su pareja, quien es obrero en una empresa D. papel, y con su hija Erica D. 26 años, en su casa propia.	Edad, estado civil, miembros D. su familia.

DesD. hace dos años y teniendo la necesidad D. realizar una labor que no sea D. mucho esfuerzo, optó por vender productos D. belleza. Por otra parte, su hija también se dedica a ello y ambas se apoyan para lograr buenas ventas, debido al carisma y buena conversación D. Florentina, pues tiene una manera muy peculiar D. ofrecer su mercadería. Ella ha probado y aprendido D. los beneficios D. sus productos, por lo cual siempre recomienda alguno gracias a la experiencia propia. 
Para el futuro, quiere tener un bazar donD. pueda mostrar y vender sus productos D. una manera más cómoda.

Este es su doceavo crédito con MFP y sigue siendo tan puntual con los pagos como lo fue con sus primeros créditos. Con el dinero que ahora solicita comprará mayor cantidad D. mercadería para incrementar su stock.
texts.en:
Florentina is 56 years old and has a lot of work experience. She lives in her own home with Félix, her partner, who works at a paper company, and her 26-year-old daughter Erica. Florentina has been selling beauty products for the past two years after she chose the traD. out of the necessity to find work that was not too strenuous. Her daughter also makes a living in cosmetics, and both support each other to achieve good sales. Florentina credits her charisma and conversation skills, and she also has a very unique way of offering her merchandise. She has tried and learned the benefits of her products, so she always has something to recommend thanks to her own experience. For the future, she wants to have a bazaar where she can display and sells her products more comfortably. This is her twelfth loan with Kiva partner MFP, and she continues to be as punctual with her payments as she was when she started. With the money she is currently requesting, she plans to purchase a larger quantity of merchandise to increase her stock.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase merchandise

loans.name: Nina

texts.en:
Nina A. is from the village of Guinsiliban , Camiguin Province. She is 20 years old. Nina is married and has 1 infant-aged children. To make a living, Nina owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling used clothing or ukay ukay as well as different types of hat in the local community. Nina has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Nina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 125 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Nina is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Nina from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Natalyia

texts.en:
Natalyia is divorced with two children – Ivan, who is 3 years old, and Yaroslav, who is 9 years old. She sells clothing at the local market in Khoost town as well as neighboring small towns. Natalyia has been in this business for four years and her income is 4,000 UAH per month.
Natalyia sells good quality clothing, and this attracts customers. This business is the only source of income for her family. She would like to borrow 6,500 UAH to purchase more inventory. She hopes to increase her sales and make additional income.

loans.use: To purchase inventory

loans.name: Kenneth

texts.en:
Kenneth is 27 years old, married to Maria Wanjiku, and they have two school-going children.  He has been a farmer for the last six years.

He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his first loan.  He plans to use the loan to buy pesticides for his farm.

In the future he plans to increase his yield and start supplying straight to the market, avoiding using middle men who eat into his share of the profits.

loans.use: To buy pesticides

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Operating capital

loans.name: Odette

texts.en:
Odette is 38 years old and is married with three children who are 1, 6 and 14 years old.

Odette has been struggling in the business of selling women’s clothes. This is her second successful year in this business which she operates from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. every day except Sunday.

Odette is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to purchase additional styles of clothes which, hopefully, will increase her profits. With these profits, she will keep reinvesting in her business and saving for a better living in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more women's clothes to sell

loans.name: Chhouk

texts.en:
S. is a 58-year-old widow and mother. She has four children: three are married and one is single. 

To earn a living, she owns a few rooms that she rents to people for a monthly fee. In this way, S. is able to generate an income to help control her family’s financial problems. She currently has other financial earners in her children who are employed at a various occupations.  

S. finds it hard to travel anywhere because she doesn’t own a vehicle. She has always hired a taxi for transportation. She wants to eliminate this expense by asking for a loan from Kiva’s project partner, HKL, to be used to purchase a new motorcycle so that she can travel without paying for a taxi.

loans.use: To purchase a new motorcycle.
